titleStmt.title: Letter from Jane Coffey to her son Diarmid Coffey, 16 October 1916
titleStmt.author: Jane Coffey

editionStmt.p: TO ADD: Letters of 1916: creating history [...]

seriesStmt.p: PUT A STATEMENT, e.g. Machine-readable transcriptions of letters from the Letters of 1916 collection

note.p: Diarmid Coffey (1888-1964) joined the Irish Volunteers in 1914 and became secretary of the Irish National Volunteers after the organisation split in 1915 (it was the other group who participated in the Rising). He later served as assistant clerk of the Seanad.
Jane Coffey (née l'Estrange) (1857-1921) was born into a Protestant family but married Catholic George Coffey and became a member of the National Literary Society.

The letter is to Diarmid from his mother and refers to a planned trip to London adding that she is glad not to have to travel to Wales instead. She does, however, also note that England is 'unpleasant' for an Irish Irelander (a cultural nationalist) just now.

samplingDecl.ab: to ADD: e.g. This electronic transcription was created as part of the crowdsourced project Letters of 1916: creating history.

div.note:
you addressed
yr letter to
Harcourt Terrace wh delayed it late
it came this
afternoon!
too late to
write
div.p:
Phyllis & Basil have
written that they come
out for weekend so
I have given up being
& hope to go
to London with them
on Monday to the Unions

& home Wed or Thursday —
It is a terrible journey
from here to Wales & I
am not sorry to give it
up — tho' I never would
neglect to see heng but
England is unpleasant
for an Irish Irelander
just now —

Mrs Finlay u has written me
a most kind invitation
& they would be a bit
sympathetic — so expect
me home Wed eve of
next week — Anne left
today she was very nice
I find her more sympathetic
than Alec just now
and will be glad
to be at home again

You can tell Margaret to
have something in —but
there is plenty of time —
& will have had enough held
by Wed. I was very much
disappointed at no letter
from you today.
div.note:
no letter How good to meet soldiers
not imperialist —
